Some additional backstory on El Salvador's dollarization

El Salvador had its own currency called the “Colones” prior to the year 2000, when the government decided to dollarize the country. It mostly benefited the bigger private entities and was designed to attract foreign investment, which it did. However, the poor class was hurt very badly by the regulations and imposing of USD. 
At the time this was implemented the exchange rate Colon/USD was around 8.50 Colones/USD. To facilitate/speed up the movement of a whole country to USD there was a lot of rounding up done in setting the new USD prices. So when people went to buy something with prices expressed in USD the rate would be something more like 9.00 – 10.00 Colones/USD. Everything had suddenly become more expensive.

This is why there still is a lot of FUD left from that change especially among the poor, it decimated their purchasing power overnight, and many don’t approve of such changes anymore. Even a common FUD right now is that foreigners will come in looking to get rid of all their Bitcoin for USD and sack the country of all its USD reserves, but again this instant convertibility is only available to Salvadoran citizens, and there already is global liquidity to anyone who desires it.
